commit_message:
Make admin-mode a CLI parameter

Admin mode enables/disables the admin endpoints. It's currently
implemented as a configuration option. It'd be useful to expose it as a
CLI parameter as well in order to ease the 'creation' of admin nodes
either from init scripts or manually without modifying the 'global'
config.

Closes-bug: #1244228
Change-Id: I3f138d8674ced180fc747c425ab85b0ed0e9e42a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/78/65078/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ] _GENERAL_CLI_OPTIONS = [ cfg.BoolOpt('admin-mode', default=False, @classmethod def register_options(cls, conf): """Registers Bootstrap's options Use this to register Bootstrap's options in `conf` before creating an instance. Options must be registered before instantiating Bootstrap. This is a temporary method that will be removed as soon as oslo.config's options registration is improved. Without it, CLI options wouldn't be registered until Bootstrap is instantiated and so, they wouldn't be exposed. :returns: The mutated conf instance. """ conf.register_opts(_GENERAL_OPTIONS) conf.register_cli_opts(_GENERAL_CLI_OPTIONS) conf.register_opts(_DRIVER_OPTIONS, group=_DRIVER_GROUP) return conf
deleted_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('admin_mode', default=False, self.conf.register_opts(_GENERAL_OPTIONS) self.conf.register_opts(_DRIVER_OPTIONS, group=_DRIVER_GROUP)

commit_message:
Allowing snapshoting attached volume

The cinder api allows calling snapshot on attached volumes,
we should enable it on horizon.

Change-Id: I33d7bbca0bf993ace7c243867aa5f57438a57a5d
Fixes: bug #1202929
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/83/57083/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: volume = cinder.volume_get(request, data['volume_id']) force = False message = _('Creating volume snapshot "%s"') % data['name'] if volume.status == 'in-use': force = True message = _('Forcing to create snapshot "%s" ' 'from in-use volume') % data['name'] force,
deleted_lines: message = _('Creating volume snapshot "%s"') % data['name']

commit_message:
Make sure a loop device exists before kpartx is called

If "kpartx -av" is called and there is no unused /dev/loop* device,
then kpartx fails. Calling "losetup -f" finds first unused device
and creates it if it doesn't exist.

Fixes bug #1195264

Change-Id: I5d59b519fd8e2a7380b71a788f9d3f2331b6567f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/56/65056/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # kpartx fails if no /dev/loop* exists, "losetup -f" prints first unused # loop device and creates it if it doesn't exist losetup -f

commit_message:
Glanceclient should switch to using bufferedhttp

Glanceclient should switch to using bufferedhttp like in swift which
makes up for missing features in traditional httplib, for eg)
buffering http headers, support for 'Expect: 100-continue' etc.
This patch pulls in the bufferedhttp from swift.

Related to bp use-buffered-http-inglance-client
Change-Id: I65f0b0f62f5d89bc8dd24b1260531e1f1d3555c8

commit_message:
Fix wrong message of pxe validator

pxe validator display wrong message, the parameters name should start
with "pxe_", else we will define wrong parameters

Change-Id: Ia2a5a001cfe01c7ef16c6d787a2d85341d718dd2
Closes-Bug: #1266143

commit_message:
Remove unused dict BYTE_MULTIPLIERS

Dict BYTE_MULTIPLIERS in ironic/common/utils.py isn't used
anywhere, and ironic/openstack/common/strutils.py includes
this dict, So we can use the one in oslo if we need. It's
safe to remove it now.

Change-Id: Iff96369057741c9a5b97fe44be7e6dd77c21ee82

commit_message:
always use sitepackages

we really don't need to be compiling lxml at 3.5 when 2.3 is good
enough. So specify that we can always use sitepackages, as well
as don't pip -U, so we use requirements as intended.

Change-Id: If9f337d6bb688d46ab68dc1276e0f499a7dec8fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/85/64985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages}sitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = Truesitepackages = True

commit_message:
Make param names more consistent in API

Param names for resource ids were inconsistent in the API. This patch
converts them to *_uuid form.

Closes-Bug: #1259619
Change-Id: Icb6cb1f9ebab7c9d516ec297eeee6f2db8b52eb2

commit_message:
Make running of unit tests more robust

Unit tests would fail if run from a symlinked directory.
To fix this, this patch adds the -P switch to the pwd command,
to make sure all files are referred to by their actual paths
and not symlinks.

Change-Id: Ib7087c11f9dc2c44be3aca8cf94db227a2db72f3
Closes-Bug: #1266220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/00/65000/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: root=`pwd -P`
deleted_lines: root=`pwd`

subject: Fix group ticket URI in KDS API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-26 10:42:01.000000000', 'files': ['openstack-identity-api/v3/src/markdown/identity-api-v3-os-kds-ext.md'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api/commit/6e0294243a5ce1c522acfc7938ead60257c00afd', 'message': 'Fix group ticket URI in KDS API

According to my understanding of the KDS API doc, the ticket retrieval
mechanism for a group destination is the same as for a single
destination. In which case, the URI used by the source to retrieve the
ticket should be the same in both case: /v1/tickets. In the current
document, the URI to be used to get a group ticket seems bogus
(/v1/groups). This patch fixes the inconsistency.

Change-Id: Ibdea2d73e8d20f821b371ed42f179dcbac2b2419
'}]
commit_message:
Fix group ticket URI in KDS API

According to my understanding of the KDS API doc, the ticket retrieval
mechanism for a group destination is the same as for a single
destination. In which case, the URI used by the source to retrieve the
ticket should be the same in both case: /v1/tickets. In the current
document, the URI to be used to get a group ticket seems bogus
(/v1/groups). This patch fixes the inconsistency.

Change-Id: Ibdea2d73e8d20f821b371ed42f179dcbac2b2419
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api refs/changes/22/64122/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove redundant body validation for createBackup

The body validation is redundant for createBackup, should remove it. In
fact that this extension is registered as WSGI action implies that the
body must contain a key with the same name as action.

Change-Id: I327688b2df50782bc38b97a4750f83a607623ce4
Closes-Bug: #1254988

commit_message:
Moves negative tests from test_absolute_limits

This change set moves the negative tests in
tempest/api/compute/limits/test_absolute_limits to
a new file test_absolute_limits_negative

Also removes usage of modules directly.

Note: HACKING.rst
The second requirement is that all negative tests must be added to
a negative test file. If such a file doesn't exist for the particular
resource being tested a new test file should be added

Change-Id: Ia331fc4089c773025e192eeef7b0546020d628b8

commit_message:
Adds simple tenant usage support for the Nova V3 API

Adds support and tests for the os-simple-tenant-usage
extension for the Nova V3 API. There are no
differences between the V2 and V3 API and this change
adds the client code to enable the usage command. Note
that with nomenclature change from tenant to project
occuring in Nova there will be a difference between
the V2 and V3 API in the future.

Differences between the V2 and V3 API are described here:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaAPIv2tov3

Partially implements blueprint v3-api

Change-Id: Iddf6211c9c87cbb191d9a5d5a65710b343c30e67

commit_message:
Updated the Identity Service/Keystone info in /common

Updated the concept info for Keystone in keystone_concepts, and commented
out duplicate information in user_management.

backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1239308

LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class _Base(): def __init__(self, client): self.client = client def request(self, path): return self.client.request(path) class StatisticsAPIClient(_Base): def get_port_statistics(self): """GET /controller/nb/v2/statistics/{containerName}/port """ # noqa return self.request('/statistics/%(container_name)s/port') def get_flow_statistics(self): """GET /controller/nb/v2/statistics/{containerName}/flow """ # noqa return self.request('/statistics/%(container_name)s/flow') def get_table_statistics(self): """GET "20", "lookupCount": "10", "matchedCount": "5", "nodeTable": { "id": "1", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" } } } ] } ] } get_flow_statistics.sample = { "flowStatistics": [ { "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" }, "flowStatistic": [ { "flow": { "match": { "matchField": [ { "type": "DL_TYPE", "value": "2048" }, { "mask": "255.255.255.255", "type": "NW_DST", "value": "1.1.1.1" } ] }, "actions": { "@type": "output", "port": { "id": "3", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" } }, "hardTimeout": "0", "id": "0", "idleTimeout": "0", "priority": "1" }, "byteCount": "0", "durationNanoseconds": "397000000", "durationSeconds": "1828", "packetCount": "0", "tableId": "0" }, { "flow": { "match": { "matchField": [ { "type": "DL_TYPE", "value": "2048" }, { "mask": "255.255.255.255", "type": "NW_DST", "value": "1.1.1.2" } ] }, "actions": { "@type": "output", "port": { "id": "4", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:03", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" } }, "hardTimeout": "0", "id": "0", "idleTimeout": "0", "priority": "1" }, "byteCount": "89", "durationNanoseconds": "200000", "durationSeconds": "5648", "packetCount": "30", "tableId": "1" } ] } ] } class TopologyAPIClient(_Base): def get_topology(self): """GET /controller/nb/v2/topology/{containerName} """ # noqa return self.request('/topology/%(container_name)s') def get_user_links(self): """GET /controller/nb/v2/topology/{containerName}/userLinks """ # noqa return self.request('/topology/%(container_name)s/userLinks') get_topology.sample = { "edgeProperties": [ { "edge": { "headNodeConnector": { "id": "2", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:51", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" }, "tailNodeConnector": { "id": "2", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" } }, "properties": { "bandwidth": { "value": 10000000000 }, "config": { "value": 1 }, "name": { "value": "s2-eth3" }, "state": { "value": 1 }, "timeStamp": { "name": "creation", "value": 1379527162648 } } }, { "edge": { "headNodeConnector": { "id": "2", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" }, "tailNodeConnector": { "id": "2", "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:51", "type": "OF" }, "type": "OF" } }, "properties": { "timeStamp": { "name": "creation", "value": 1379527162648 } } } ] } get_user_links.sample = { "userLinks": [ { "dstNodeConnector": "OF|5@OF|00:00:00:00:00:00:00:05", "name": "link1", "srcNodeConnector": "OF|2@OF|00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "status": "Success" } ] } class SwitchManagerAPIClient(_Base): def get_nodes(self): """GET /controller/nb/v2/switchmanager/{containerName}/nodes """ # noqa return self.request('/switchmanager/%(container_name)s/nodes') get_nodes.sample = { "nodeProperties": [ { "node": { "id": "00:00:00:00:00:00:00:02", "type": "OF" }, "properties": { "actions": { "value": "4095" }, "buffers": { "value": "256" }, "capabilities": { "value": "199" }, "description": { "value": "None" }, "macAddress": { "value": "00:00:00:00:00:02" }, "tables": { "value": "-1" }, "timeStamp": { "name": "connectedSince", "value": "1377291227877" } } } ] } class Client(): def __init__(self, endpoint, params): self.statistics = StatisticsAPIClient(self) self.topology = TopologyAPIClient(self) self.switch_manager = SwitchManagerAPIClient(self) self._endpoint = endpoint self._container_name = params.get('container', 'default') self._req_params = { 'headers': { 'Accept': 'application/json' } } self._user = params.get('user') self._password = params.get('password') if self._user is not None: self._req_params['auth'] = auth.HTTPBasicAuth(self._user[0], self._password[0]) def _log_req(self, url): curl_command = 'curl -i -X GET ' curl_command += '"' + url + '" ' curl_command += '--user "%s":"%s" ' % (self._user[0], self._password[0]) for name, value in six.iteritems(self._req_params['headers']): curl_command += '-H "%s: %s"' % (name, value) LOG.info(curl_command) def _http_request(self, url): self._log_req(url) resp = requests.get(url, **self._req_params) return resp.json() def request(self, path): url = self._endpoint + path % {'container_name': self._container_name} return self._http_request(url)

subject: Move extension example docs around
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-15 07:44:18.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/extensions/example-configuration.rst', 'keystone/contrib/example/README.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/2fe6402769bb6c4688eb9aa462c6f537dac868d4', 'message': 'Move extension example docs around

Noticed that the configuration.rst file for the example extension
was not under docs.

The patch moved the file to docs, but does not link it back in the
configuration.rst file.

Also added a README file to the example extension that reminds
authors to place docs in the right spot.

Change-Id: If57bf08195b184346bcbfb6bbc7e037bf48b6c9e
'}]
commit_message:
Move extension example docs around

Noticed that the configuration.rst file for the example extension
was not under docs.

The patch moved the file to docs, but does not link it back in the
configuration.rst file.

Also added a README file to the example extension that reminds
authors to place docs in the right spot.

Change-Id: If57bf08195b184346bcbfb6bbc7e037bf48b6c9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/18/62218/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================== Extension Development ===================== The files seen in keystone/contrib/example are meant to act as a guideline. When adding a new extension to Keystone, please also: 1. Add documentation on how to configure the extension by adding a new file under doc/source/extensions. 2. Creating a new section in the doc/source/configuration.rst file for the new extension that references the newly added configuration documentation.

commit_message:
Remove test_auth_token.py

The tests in test_auth_token didn't really add an value. They just
ran a server list command and hoped it didn't throw an exception. If
there was an issue with this then all the api tests would fail, so
there is no value in these tests.

Change-Id: I14e0c0284170219c028454990f189440ffeb0b08

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2013 IBM Corp # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest import test class AuthTokenTestJSON(base.BaseV2ComputeTest): _interface = 'json' @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(AuthTokenTestJSON, cls).setUpClass() cls.servers_v2 = cls.os.servers_client cls.servers_v3 = cls.os.servers_client_v3_auth def test_v2_token(self): # Can get a token using v2 of the identity API and use that to perform # an operation on the compute service. # Doesn't matter which compute API is used, # picking list_servers because it's easy. self.servers_v2.list_servers() @test.skip_because(condition=False, group='identity', option='uri_v3', msg='v3 auth client not configured') def test_v3_token(self): # Can get a token using v3 of the identity API and use that to perform # an operation on the compute service. # Doesn't matter which compute API is used, # picking list_servers because it's easy. self.servers_v3.list_servers() class AuthTokenTestXML(AuthTokenTestJSON): _interface = 'xml'

commit_message:
Removes disk-config extension from v3 api

This patch removes disk-config extension for v3 api, and also
remove related tests. And remove resize extension point for
servers core because there isn't any extension using it anymore
and there isn't good way to test resize extension point.

Implements bp api-v3-remove-disk-config
DocImpact

Change-Id: I894ae6f4e0d6c9f956a71e8e061ccb3fa1b039d8

subject: Implement API for provisioning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-10 16:18:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/274eae6efc3e46591b7d07318aa467162d1d3d4c', 'message': "Add trigger to start provisioning the node

Expose in the API a way to trigger the provisioning of a node. Client have
to do a PUT at /nodes/<uuid>/states/provision and in the body request
indicate the desired provision state for that node. In the moment only
'active' is a valid state, more states can be added later (for e.g to
trigger the unprovovision of the node). Also this call is async and
will return 202 (Accepted) in case the request was accepted and is in
progress. It will also return 409 (Conflict) in case there's a state
change already in progress or 400 if the supplied desired state is not
valid. No body message is returned, client should continue to GET the
status of the node to observe the status of the request, in the future
an URL to the /states subresource of the node should be added to the
Location header indicating that, right now setting the Location header
is not supported by WSME.

Change-Id: Iff315ccae9101b9736e3b9cc557cac01c26ac257
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-17 18:08:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/33d48f3426ee95be6b655b2dca6ca1e278a175cf', 'message': "Add trigger to start provisioning the node

Expose in the API a way to trigger the provisioning of a node. Client have
to do a PUT at /nodes/<uuid>/states/provision and in the body request
indicate the desired provision state for that node. In the moment only
'active' is a valid state, more states can be added later (for e.g to
trigger the unprovovision of the node). Also this call is async and
will return 202 (Accepted) in case the request was accepted and is in
progress. It will also return 409 (Conflict) in case there's a state
change already in progress or 400 if the supplied desired state is not
valid. No body message is returned, client should continue to GET the
status of the node to observe the status of the request, in the future
an URL to the /states subresource of the node should be added to the
Location header indicating that, right now setting the Location header
is not supported by WSME.

Change-Id: Iff315ccae9101b9736e3b9cc557cac01c26ac257
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-01-03 17:34:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/ec697dfa14517b22ca843fc1633578bd8de376a4', 'message': "Add trigger to start provisioning the node

Expose do_node_deploy and do_node_tear_down in the API for /nodes/states.

Client have to do a PUT at /nodes/<uuid>/states/provision and in the body
request indicate the desired provision state for that node. This is async
call and will return 202 (Accepted) in case the request was accepted
and is in progress. It will also return 409 (Conflict) in case there's

commit_message:
Implement API for provisioning

Expose do_node_deploy and do_node_tear_down in the API for /nodes/states.

Client have to do a PUT at /nodes/<uuid>/states/provision and in the body
request indicate the desired provision state for that node. This is an
async call and will return 202 (Accepted) in case the request was accepted
and is in progress. It will also return 409 (Conflict) in case there's
a state change already in progress or 400 if the supplied desired state
is not valid or if the node is already in the requested state. No body
message is returned, client should continue to GET the status of the node
to observe the status of the request, in the future an URL to the /states
subresource of the node should be added to the Location header indicating
that, right now setting the Location header is not supported by WSME.

Change-Id: Iff315ccae9101b9736e3b9cc557cac01c26ac257
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/60/61160/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.common import states as ir_states 'provision': ['PUT'], msg = (_('Power operation for node %s is already in progress.') % rpc_node['uuid']) LOG.exception(msg) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(msg, status_code=409) # FIXME(lucasagomes): Currently WSME doesn't support returning # the Location header. Once it's implemented we should use the # Location to point to the /states subresource of the node so # that clients will know how to track the status of the request # https://bugs.launchpad.net/wsme/+bug/1233687 @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, wtypes.text, wtypes.text, status_code=202) def provision(self, node_uuid, target): """Asynchronous trigger the provisioning of the node. This will set the target provision state of the node, and a background task will begin which actually applies the state change. This call will return a 202 (Accepted) indicating the request was accepted and is in progress; the client should continue to GET the status of this node to observe the status of the requested action. :param node_uuid: UUID of the node. :param target: Desired provision state. Only supports 'active' for the moment. :raises: InvalidParameterValue """ rpc_node = objects.Node.get_by_uuid(pecan.request.context, node_uuid) # Check if it's already being provisioned if rpc_node.target_provision_state is not None: msg = _('Node %s is already being provisioned.') % rpc_node['uuid'] LOG.exception(msg) raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(msg, status_code=409) if target == ir_states.ACTIVE: pecan.request.rpcapi.do_node_deploy(pecan.request.context, rpc_node) else: msg = _("Target provision state '%s' not supported.") % target LOG.exception(msg) raise exception.InvalidParameterValue(msg) # FIXME(lucasagomes): Currently WSME doesn't support returning # the Location header. Once it's implemented we should use the # Location to point to the /states subresource of this node so # that clients will know how to track the status of the request # https://bugs.launchpad.net/wsme/+bug/1233687
deleted_lines: raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(_("Power operation for node %s is " "already in progress.") % rpc_node['uuid'], status_code=409) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(NodeStates, wtypes.text, wtypes.text, status_code=202) def provision(node_uuid, target): """Set the provision state of the node.""" # TODO(lucasagomes): Test if target is a valid state and if it's able # to transition to the target state from the current one raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
API to validate UUID parameters

The patch uses the UuidType in the wsexpose decorator to make WSME
validate whether UUIDs parameters are UUID-like strings. By doing that,
it solves the problem of allowing ports to be accessed by its address,
which is an inconsistence in our API.

As our UuidType now differs from the UuidType of WSME the patch also
removes the note to remove our custom type on the next WSME release.

Change-Id: I023e8f31d94555577c4573b4a5cf0d649d33b4fa
Closes-Bug: #1246816

Expose do_node_deploy and do_node_tear_down
in the REST API for /nodes/states.

commit_message:
Fix regression in Rackspace Cloud Servers tests

Commit 63b7f14403 introduced a regression in the Rackspace Cloud Server
tests.  Instance.volumes() now relies on its VOLUME property's default.
Since CloudServer inherits volumes() from Instance but defines its own
VOLUMES property, its VOLUMES property should also have a default.

Closes-Bug: #1265034
Change-Id: Ib17337c5d06aedf65da5497ad48858d649ba4e96

commit_message:
Add negative tests for routers

Create a base class for negative and positive router tests
Add some negative tests for router

Change-Id: I00ea78bc0729f1f28a665b5135ce202a462b7e32
Implements: blueprint add-test-neutron-tempest-negative-test-routers

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.network import base_routers as base from tempest.common.utils.data_utils import rand_name from tempest import exceptions from tempest.test import attr import uuid class NegativeRoutersTest(base.BaseRouterTest): _interface = 'json' @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(NegativeRoutersTest, cls).setUpClass() cls.router = cls.create_router(rand_name('router-')) cls.network = cls.create_network() cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_router_add_gateway_invalid_network_returns_404(self): self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.update_router, self.router['id'], external_gateway_info={ 'network_id': self.router['id']}) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_router_add_gateway_no_subnet_returns_400(self): network_no_subnet = self.create_network() self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.update_router, self.router['id'], external_gateway_info={ 'network_id': network_no_subnet['id']}) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_router_add_gateway_net_not_external_returns_400(self): subnet = self.create_subnet(self.network) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.update_router, self.router['id'], external_gateway_info={ 'network_id': self.network['id']}) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_router_remove_interface_inuse_returns_409(self): self.client.add_router_interface_with_subnet_id( self.router['id'], self.subnet['id']) self.assertRaises(exceptions.Conflict, self.client.delete_router, self.router['id'])

commit_message:
Moves negative tests from test_server_addresses

This change set moves the negative tests in
tempest/api/compute/servers/test_server_addresses
to a new file test_server_addresses_negative

Also removes usage of modules directly.

Note: HACKING.rst
The second requirement is that all negative tests must be added to a negative
test file. If such a file doesn't exist for the particular resource being
tested a new test file should be added

commit_message:
Fix to check "Response Status" in the "Response Body"

Swift docs[1] says:
------------------------------
The response is similar to bulk deletes as in every response will be a
200 OK and you must parse the response body for actual results.
------------------------------
However, test_delete_large_object doesn't check it.
This commit fix it.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/misc.html#module-swift.common.middleware.bulk

Change-Id: If58395823718e07ba41ded00540b9362b729d0e9
Closes-Bug: #1264064
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/11/64011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertIn(test.HTTP_SUCESS, body['Response Status'])

subject: Replace Simple/Chance Scheduler with FilterScheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-23 17:10:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/456ac666d5845bacdd324d93bf4978e90c654bed', 'message': "Replace Simple/Chance Scheduler with FilterScheduler

This patch replaces SimpleScheduler and ChanceScheduler with
FilterScheduler.  Scheduler manager is changed so that when it
detects 'scheduler_driver' is set to SimpleScheduler or
ChanceScheduler, it changes underlying scheduler driver to
FilterScheduler, and then host manager will use a pre-defined
combination of filters & weighers to keep scheduler behavior *MOSTLY*
the same as its old counterparts.

To simulate ChanceScheduler/SimpleScheduler, 'AvailabilityZoneFilter',
'CapacityFilter' and 'CapabilitiesFilter' are chosen to filter
out hosts that isn't in the target AZ, doesn't have sufficient
capacity and doesn't support needed capabilities.  And newly
added 'ChanceWeigher' will randomly pick a host from hosts
that passes above filters - just like ChanceScheduler does;
for SimpleScheduler, 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher' will sort hosts
with their 'allocated_capacity' - the one allocates the least
is the winner by default.

So the two new weigher, 'ChanceWeigher' and 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher'
are the key FilterScheduler to act identical when choosing
back-ends to serve requests.  The filters on the other hand,
are essential to make sure 'new' Simple/Chance Scheduler can support
volume types, encrpytion and QoS.

Partially implements bp: deprecate-chance-and-simple-schedulers

Change-Id: I0538b9692a23af6457ed463447fea8e564570848

commit_message:
Replace Simple/Chance Scheduler with FilterScheduler

This patch replaces SimpleScheduler and ChanceScheduler with
FilterScheduler. Scheduler manager is changed so that when it
detects 'scheduler_driver' is set to SimpleScheduler or
ChanceScheduler, it changes underlying scheduler driver to
FilterScheduler, and then host manager will use a pre-defined
combination of filters & weighers to keep scheduler behavior *MOSTLY*
the same as its old counterparts.

To simulate ChanceScheduler/SimpleScheduler, 'AvailabilityZoneFilter',
'CapacityFilter' and 'CapabilitiesFilter' are chosen to filter
out hosts that isn't in the target AZ, doesn't have sufficient
capacity and doesn't support needed capabilities. And newly
added 'ChanceWeigher' will randomly pick a host from hosts
that passes above filters - just like ChanceScheduler does;
for SimpleScheduler, 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher' will sort hosts
with their 'allocated_capacity' - the one allocates the least
is the winner by default.

So the two new weigher, 'ChanceWeigher' and 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher'
are the key FilterScheduler to act identical when choosing
back-ends to serve requests. The 3 filters on the other hand,
are essential to make sure this 'new' Simple/Chance Scheduler can
support volume types, encryption and QoS.

Partially implements bp: deprecate-chance-and-simple-schedulers

Change-Id: I0538b9692a23af6457ed463447fea8e564570848
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/94/63794/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.import_opt('scheduler_driver', 'cinder.scheduler.manager') self.filter_classes = self.filter_handler.get_all_classes() default_filters = ['AvailabilityZoneFilter', 'CapacityFilter', 'CapabilitiesFilter'] if str(CONF.scheduler_driver).find('simple'): CONF.scheduler_default_filters = default_filters CONF.scheduler_default_weighers = ['AllocatedCapacityWeigher'] elif str(CONF.scheduler_driver).find('chance'): CONF.scheduler_default_filters = default_filters CONF.scheduler_default_weighers = ['ChanceWeigher'] else: # FilterScheduler is directly configured, keep default # filters and weights. pass
deleted_lines: self.filter_classes = self.filter_handler.get_all_classes()

subject: Filter resource types by support status
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-07 15:54:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/97d3e700e5a75816c143e1d2630031cbf9dd868e', 'message': "Filter resource types by support status

Add extra argument 'support_status' to list_resource_types
function in heat/api and heat/engine. It allows to filter results
by support status when querying the api for resource types.

Add new field 'support_status' to ResourceInfo class.
support_status='UNKNOWN' by default.

Add new function 'get_types_with_status' to
ResourceRegistry and Environment classes in
heat/engine/environment.py. Function 'get_types_with_status'
from ResourceRegistry class returns resource types filtered
by support_status.

Add function 'get_types_with_status' to
heat/engine/resource.py. It returns an iterator over the list
of resource types with current status.

Add suitable changes to tests:
- heat/tests/test_api_openstack_v1.py
- heat/tests/test_engine_service.py
- heat/tests/test_rpc_client.py

Implements bp filter-resources-by-support

commit_message:
Filter resource types by support status

Now heat resources haven't support status. We want service providers
to have a way to assign support status metadata to resources. And
then user should be able to filter resource types by support status
when quering the api for resource types.

Add processing of query parameter support_status to list_resource_types
function in heat/api to filter resources by. List_resource_types
returns a list of resources with a certain status or a list of all
resource types by default.

Add filtering on the server.

Add changes to tests:
- test_rpc_client.py
- test_api_openstack_v1.py
- test_engine_service.py

Implements bp filter-resources-by-support

Change-Id: I719c0d690886153adb698aea4695ddd526e7a4af

commit_message:
Return 403 for exception.Forbidden exceptions

Currently the following Glance v1 operations:
    - Deleting a member from an image
    - Updating image membership
    - Updating all members of an image
return HTTPNotFound even when the underlying system returns
exception.Forbidden.

This commit returns the corresponding HTTP errors.

Change-Id: Ibd34d515b83f658bbca2d102d6b582faf118faa6
Closes-bug: #1199359

commit_message:
Deleted TEMPDIR on exit

To avoid undeleted tmp.XXXXXXXXX directories left in /tmp, and output
unified style patch for later apply.

Change-Id: I6069c3cf36e345e5101ae3cf884e647c1d42030e

commit_message:
Make LoadBalancer nested stack template configurable

Reviving work originally posted by Angus Salkeld under
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21405/

This is to enable the various distros to easily override the
hard-coded default nested template (which currently only supports
Fedora 17) with a template approporate to their distro, and
enables deployers to specify their own template (although the
latter use-case will probably be catered for via a provider
template implementation long-term).

Change-Id: I0a4eccb23b2eebbf31b7aabf0fe85ab31f0ca971
Partial-Bug: #1234375
Co-Authored-By: Angus Salkeld <angus@salkeld.id.au>

commit_message:
Add test coverage for SignalResponder delete

Add coverage for the case where the user has been deleted out of band
and keystoneclient raises a NotFound exception.  Brings coverage of
SignalResponder up to 100%

Change-Id: I29ea94b052f807072d98e05768e6a1973df5d40d

added_lines: def test_delete_not_found(self): self.stack = self.create_stack(stack_name='test_delete_not_found', stub=False) class FakeKeystoneClientFail(fakes.FakeKeystoneClient): def delete_stack_user(self, name): raise kc_exceptions.NotFound() self.m.StubOutWithMock(clients.OpenStackClients, 'keystone') clients.OpenStackClients.keystone().MultipleTimes().AndReturn( FakeKeystoneClientFail()) self.m.ReplayAll() self.stack.create() rsrc = self.stack['signal_handler'] self.assertEqual(rsrc.state, (rsrc.CREATE, rsrc.COMPLETE)) scheduler.TaskRunner(rsrc.delete)() self.assertEqual(rsrc.state, (rsrc.DELETE, rsrc.COMPLETE)) self.m.VerifyAll() @utils.stack_delete_after

commit_message:
Add policy enforcement to ReST API

Currently the native API lacks support for enforcing policy via
policy.json, as is possible for the aws-compatible APIs.

So modify and rename the tenant_local decorator to also enforce
policy, and add tests to ensure the API controllers are all
using the decorator on their actions

Change-Id: Id80d576d5ff5e546da42dbf08ebd653005af14ff
blueprint: request-scoping-policy

deleted_lines: def enforce(self, context, action, target=None): _action = '%s:%s' % (self.scope, action)

Improve README

Rename to README.rst for nicer formatting and add additional
information.

Change-Id: I119248e33258c1d40d222034cb5e06e1bfaec93c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/90/64990/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: API-Site Repository +++++++++++++++++++ This repository contains documentation for the OpenStack project. For more details, see the `OpenStack Documentation wiki page <http://wiki.openstack.org/Documentation>`_. It includes these manuals: * API Quick Start * API Complete Reference In addition to these, this repository contains: * api.openstack.org: ``www`` Prerequisites ============= `Apache Maven <http://maven.apache.org/>`_ must be installed to build the documentation. To install Maven 3 for Ubuntu 12.04 and later,and Debian wheezy and later:: apt-get install maven On Fedora 15 and later:: yum install maven3 Building ======== The manuals are in the ``api-quick-start`` and ``api-ref`` directories. To build a specific guide, look for a ``pom.xml`` file within a subdirectory, then run the ``mvn`` command in that directory. For example:: cd api-quick-start mvn clean generate-sources The generated PDF documentation file is:: api-quick-start/target/docbkx/webhelp/api-quick-start-onepager-external/api-quick-start-onepager.pdf The root of the generated HTML documentation is:: api-quick-start/target/docbkx/webhelp/api-quick-start-onepager-external/content/index.html Testing of changes and building of the manual ============================================= Install the python tox package and run ``tox`` from the top-level directory to use the same tests that are done as part of our Jenkins gating jobs. If you like to run individual tests, run: * ``tox -e checkniceness`` - to run the niceness tests * ``tox -e checksyntax`` - to run syntax checks * ``tox -e checkdeletions`` - to check that no deleted files are referenced * ``tox -e checkbuild`` - to actually build the manual tox will use the `openstack-doc-tools package <https://github.com/openstack/openstack-doc-tools>`_ for execution of these tests. openstack-doc-tools has a requirement on maven for the build check. Contributing ============ Our community welcomes all people interested in open source cloud computing, and encourages you to join the `OpenStack Foundation <http://www.openstack.org/join>`_. The best way to get involved with the community is to talk with others online or at a meetup and offer contributions through our processes, the `OpenStack wiki <http://wiki.openstack.org>`_, blogs, or on IRC at ``#openstack`` on ``irc.freenode.net``. We welcome all types of contributions, from blueprint designs to documentation to testing to deployment scripts. If you would like to contribute to the documents, you must follow the steps in the "If you're a developer, start here" section of this page: http://wiki.openstack.org/HowToContribute Bugs ==== Bugs should be filed on Launchpad, not GitHub: https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-api-site/ Installing ========== Refer to http://docs.openstack.org to see where these documents are published and to learn more about the OpenStack project.

Adopt for using openstack-doc-tools

Allow building and testing with openstack-doc-tools package.

Add README to explain repositoriy and tools usage.

commit_message:
Allow empty response in service-list

If a user runs 'nova service-list --binary something-weird', where
something-weird is a binary that is not listed the result is a confusing
IndexError. That is because the result is expected to always have at
least one result.

Part of the reason for that is that the fake client does not make it
easy to simulate an empty response in tests. That is why there is no
regression test associated with this bug-fix. That is also why I am
marking thas as Partial-Bug, as this corrects the symptom, but it does
not prevent it from regressing.

Change-Id: I3e6798d63a662c245196b3bf95bb7e1b0ea9c3a4
Partial-Bug: #1260504

commit_message:
Do not override cloud-init cloud_config_modules

In the past it may have been necessary to do this but it causes problems
for users of advanced features. We should be able to operate with the
default OS configuration of cloud-init.

Change-Id: Ic26bffb17b1870d656fea72cf3da3dfe2b7f44d0
Closes-Bug: #1263297

commit_message:
Make scheduler rpcapi use object serializer

The scheduler rpcapi is still using NoOpSerializer which can't serialize
objects. When testing with objects for instance flavor, filter_properties
can not be serialized because its structure is:

{'instance_type': <nova.objects.flavor.Flavor object at 0x6862d10>,
'scheduler_hints': {}}

If the scheduler uses objects, its serializer can not be NoOPSerializer.

Related to blueprint icehouse-objects.

Change-Id: I0a9a02eefc051738183e0393ae0c462d60c74fef

In AvailabilityZoneFilter, if request_spec does not include

commit_message:
Fix coding error in AvailabilityZoneFilter

In AvailabilityZoneFilter, if request_spec does not include
resource_properties, AvailabilityZoneFilter will set default value
of resource_properties as [], this is not right, we should use {}
instead.

Oslo is correct and was using {} as default value.

Change-Id: Id5fa13c0353eb5213ec828d98770955a9d6a1b03

commit_message:
Adding cinder benchmark scenarios for Rally

The patch providers Rally with the basic Cinder benchmark scenario
for create/delete volume:these include create and delete volume.

Blueprint benchmark-scenarios

Change-Id: Iff85045013ce61a0632d4063ae7866f51d9e6c26

commit_message:
Fixes for building

* Fix path to ha build script
* Do not force building of books if --api-site is given, the code
  is correct, it just falls over invalid xml. Patches have been
  sent to fix the XML.
* Validate also XML files that are in samples directory or
  in wadls directory - but only validate for proper XML, do not
  validate against any schema

Change-Id: Ifca12ddf8f3fbd23bacf77e4d5930e450162ee05

commit_message:
generalize use of array for $alarm_package_name

ceilometer::params::alarm_package_name was an array on Debian and
a string on RedHat.

The patch also simplify the Package  Service relationship declaration.
Package are now only declared in init.php to avoid the case a
Package['ceilometer-alarm'] was declared two time (evaluator.pp and
notifier.pp).

Change-Id: If1e52623c5f3fee6edf7157b5e2d63e004385900
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/26/64926/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: hasrestart => true, require => $::ceilometer::params::alarm_package_name
deleted_lines: Package['ceilometer-alarm'] -> Service['ceilometer-alarm-notifier'] if !defined(Package['ceilometer-alarm']){ package { 'ceilometer-alarm': ensure => installed, name => $::ceilometer::params::alarm_package_name, } } Package['ceilometer-common'] -> Service['ceilometer-alarm-notifier'] hasrestart => true

commit_message:
Adds floating-IP tracker to cross_tenant scenario

check that floating IPs have propagated to VM before ping/SSH

Fails sometimes due to bug 1262529

Change-Id: I1a13a7339872fbf452aa6802a92adc28b67ddb91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/97/62697/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _wait_for_floating_ip_association(self, tenant_id): # convert floating_ip dict to match FloatingIPCheckTracker floating_ip_map = {} for server, floating_ip in self.floating_ips.items(): if server.tenant_id == tenant_id: floating_ip_map[floating_ip] = server ip_tracker = FloatingIPCheckTracker(self.compute_client, floating_ip_map) self.assertTrue( call_until_true(ip_tracker.run_checks, self.config.compute.build_timeout, self.config.compute.build_interval), "Timed out while waiting for the floating IP assignments " "to propagate") self._wait_for_floating_ip_association(tenant_id)

commit_message:
Remove start index 0 in range()

Remove the useless arg ("start index" = 0) in files, since its default
value is 0, to make code cleaner.

Change-Id: I18c5f616ab0f3cf30f0a2486d7cc38684974586d
Closes-Bug: #1262679

commit_message:
Change shards & catalogue db into single property

Refactoring the shards and catalogue mongo database methods into a
single method because there's no need for these to access different
logical databases.

Change-Id: Ia75df73dcdb31e88473878f6c55abcf159f1aa44
Closes-Bug: #1246373

commit_message:
removed unused context in check_*** methods

Input parameter 'context' of Check_*** methods(check_attach,
check_detach, _check_metadata_properties, _check_volume_availability)
in cinder/volume/api.py are not being used, so remove this 'context'
parameter.

Change-Id: I314f662f2fe54a6b073181ff5c0f0214e9ef822a
Closes-bug: #1265725
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/99/64799/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def check_attach(self, volume): def check_detach(self, volume): self._check_metadata_properties(metadata) def _check_metadata_properties(self, metadata=None): self._check_metadata_properties(_metadata) self._check_metadata_properties(_metadata) self._check_metadata_properties(_metadata) def _check_volume_availability(self, volume, force): self._check_volume_availability(volume, force)
deleted_lines: def check_attach(self, context, volume): def check_detach(self, context, volume): self._check_metadata_properties(context, metadata) def _check_metadata_properties(self, context, metadata=None): self._check_metadata_properties(context, _metadata) self._check_metadata_properties(context, _metadata) self._check_metadata_properties(context, _metadata) def _check_volume_availability(self, context, volume, force): self._check_volume_availability(context, volume, force)

subject: add 'force' verification in _volume_upload_image
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-03 08:00:20.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/api/contrib/volume_actions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/04e333f78ec8f22cdc0f0ab8701ae6a277bacbd5', 'message': "add 'force' verification in _volume_upload_image

_volume_upload_image API should only support to upload 'in-use' volume to
image when assign 'force' parameter as true value. Now
_volume_upload_image API does not do verification for 'force' parameter,
so we can upload 'in-use' volume to image when assign 'force' parameter
with string value 'false' or 'false111'. This patch add verification for
'force' parameter.

Change-Id: I9e1d0e517d0ff97c136903dd6e50a305e18651f3
Closes-Bug: #1265718
"}]
commit_message:
add 'force' verification in _volume_upload_image

_volume_upload_image API should only support to upload 'in-use' volume to
image when assign 'force' parameter as true value. Now
_volume_upload_image API does not do verification for 'force' parameter,
so we can upload 'in-use' volume to image when assign 'force' parameter
with string value 'false' or 'false111'. This patch add verification for
'force' parameter.

Change-Id: I9e1d0e517d0ff97c136903dd6e50a305e18651f3
Closes-Bug: #1265718
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/94/64794/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if isinstance(force, basestring): try: force = strutils.bool_from_string(force, strict=False) except ValueError: msg = _("Bad value for 'force' parameter.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) elif not isinstance(force, bool): msg = _("'force' is not string or bool.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

commit_message:
Fix race in get_network(s) in OVS plugin

Load network bindings eagerly with networks.
Otherwise a different db query could try to fetch network bindings
for already deleted networks. The issue is reproducible with
concurrent tempest network API tests.

Closes-Bug: 1263686
Change-Id: I0521ab162220c66a62491ff8e7e4a9f6d7bef6c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/18/63918/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def _extend_network_dict_provider(self, context, network): binding = ovs_db_v2.get_network_binding(context.session, network['id']) self._extend_network_dict_provider(context, net) self._extend_network_dict_provider(context, net) self._extend_network_dict_provider(context, net) for net in nets: self._extend_network_dict_provider(context, net)

commit_message:
unify keypair name handling

CreateKeyPair and ImportKeypair handled name checks in a different
way. When importing a keypair, one got a generic error message
without a hint, that the name was wrong.

Change-Id: Ie82c0cd21f70aae3f55b84a1c05c9f170eaec312
Closes-Bug: #1265563

Partially-implements blueprint django-1point6

commit_message:
Remove the 'cmp' keyword from a call to 'sort()'

This keyword does not exist in Python 3, and 'key' should be used instead.

Change-Id: I0f92a1e3d389b491bf138c215e11e68fddc15477
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/50/61550/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: keys.sort(key=six.text_type.lower)
deleted_lines: keys.sort(cmp=lambda x, y: cmp(x.lower(), y.lower()))

commit_message:
Add general ceilometer concepts to guide

  The CLI guide did not contain the details of concepts such
  as meter, statistics and alarm. Since the next
  paragraphs included the commands to obtain these values, this
  would be confusing for newcomers.

  The fix includes the description of the concepts prior to the
  commands.

Change-Id: Ifdcc0e282e74838b9c420b140976c5767a06451b
Closes-Bug: #1263500
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/64/64664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Ceilometer uses several concepts to model the Telemetry data. <itemizedlist> <listitem>Meters measure a particular aspect of resource usage (e.g. the existence of a running instance) or of ongoing performance (e.g. the current CPU utilization % for that instance). As such meters exist per-resource, in that there is a separate cpu_util meter for example for each instance. The lifecycle of meters is also decoupled from the existence of the related resources, in the sense that the meter continues to exist after the resource has been terminated. All meters have a string name, a unit of measurement, and a type indicating whether values are monotonically increasing (cumulative), interpreted as a change from the previous value (delta), or a standalone value relating only to the current duration (gauge).</listitem> <listitem>Sample are simply individual datapoints associated with a particular meter. As such, all samples encompass the same attributes as the meter itself, but with the addition of a timestamp and and a value (otherwise known as the sample 'volume').</listtem> <listitem>A statistic is a set of such datapoints aggregates over a time durationi (as opposed to a sample which is a single datapoint). Ceilometer currently employs 5 different aggregation functions: <itemizedlist> <listitem>count: the number of samples in each period</listitem> <listitem>max: the maxima of the sample volumes in each period</listitem> <listitem>min: the minima of the sample volumes in each period</listitem> <listitem>avg: the average of the sample volumes over each period</listitem> <listitem>sum: the sum of the sample volumes over each period</listitem> </itemizedlist></listitem> <listitem>Alarms provide user-oriented Monitoring-as-a-Service for Openstack, with Heat autoscaling being a typical use-case, but also having general purpose utility. An alarm is a set of rules defining a monitor, plus a current state, with edge-triggered actions associated with target states. These alarms follow a tri-state model of ok, alarm, and insufficient data. For conventional threshold-oriented alarms, state transitions are governed by a static threshold value & comparison operator against which a selected meter statistic is compared over an evaluation window of configurable length into the recent past.</listitem> </itemizedlist></para>

commit_message:
Move Networking scenarios section from Configuration Reference to Cloud Admin Guide

Moved networking-config-identity, networking-scenarios,
networking-adv-config, networking-multi-dhcp-agents from Config Ref to
Networking ch of Cloud Admin Guide

Change-Id: I1c14e9b7017fee976c2c80b6f0c8c7bcb15eb046
backport: none
Closes-Bug: #1255295
author: nermina miller
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/69/63569/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Networking must be available in the Compute service catalog. Create the service: The way that you create a Networking endpoint entry depends on whether you are using the SQL catalog driver or the template catalog driver: If you use the SQL driver, run these command with these parameters: specified region ($REGION), IP address of the Networking server ($IP), and service ID ($NEUTRON_SERVICE_ID, obtained in the previous step). If you are using the template driver, add the following content to your Compute catalog template file (default_catalog.templates), using these parameters: given region ($REGION) and IP address of the Networking server ($IP). You must provide admin user credentials that Compute and some internal Networking components can use to access the Networking API. The suggested approach is to create a special service tenant, create a neutron user within this tenant, and to assign this user an admin role. If you use Networking, do not run the Compute nova-network service (like you do in traditional Compute deployments). Instead, Compute delegates most network-related decisions to Networking. Compute proxies tenant-facing API calls to manage security groups and floating IPs to Networking APIs. However, operator-facing tools such as nova-manage, are not proxied and should not be used. When you configure networking, you must use this guide. Do not rely on Compute networking documentation or past experience with Compute. If a nova command or configuration option related to networking is not mentioned in this guide, the command is probably not supported for use with Networking. In particular, you cannot use CLI tools like nova-manage and nova to manage networks or IP addressing, including both fixed and floating IPs, with Networking. It is strongly recommended that you uninstall nova-network and reboot any physical nodes that have been running nova-network before using them to run Networking. Inadvertently running the nova-network process while using Networking can cause problems, as can stale iptables rules pushed down by previously running nova-network. To ensure that Compute works properly with Networking (rather than the legacy nova-network mechanism), you must adjust settings in the nova.conf configuration file. Each time a VM is provisioned or de-provisioned in Compute, nova-* services communicate with Networking using the standard API. For this to happen, you must configure the following items in the nova.conf file (used by each nova-compute and nova-api instance). Modify from the default to nova.network.neutronv2.api.API, to indicate that Networking should be used rather than the traditional nova-network networking model. Update to the name of the service tenant created in the above section on Identity Update to the name of the user created in the above section on Identity configuration. Update to the password of the user created in the above section on Identity configuration. Update to the Identity server IP and port. This is the Identity (keystone) admin API server IP and port value, and not the Identity service API IP and port. The Networking Service provides security group functionality using a mechanism that is more flexible and powerful than the security group capabilities built into Compute. Therefore, if you use Networking, you should always disable built-in security groups and proxy all security group calls to the Networking API . If you do not, security policies will conflict by being simultaneously applied by both services. To proxy security groups to Networking, use the following configuration values in nova.conf: Update to neutron, so that all security group requests are proxied to the The Compute service allows VMs to query metadata associated with a VM by making a web request to a special 169.254.169.254 address. Networking supports proxying those requests to nova-api, even when the requests are made from isolated networks, or from multiple networks that use overlapping IP addresses. Example values for the above settings, assuming a cloud controller node running Compute and Networking with an IP address of 192.168.1.2.
deleted_lines: OpenStack Networking must be available in the OpenStack Compute service catalog. Create the service: The way that you create an OpenStack Networking endpoint entry depends on whether you are using the SQL catalog driver or the template catalog driver: If you use the SQL driver, run these command with these parameters: specified region ($REGION), IP address of the OpenStack Networking server ($IP), and service ID ($NEUTRON_SERVICE_ID, obtained in the previous step). If you are using the template driver, add the following content to your OpenStack Compute catalog template file (default_catalog.templates), using these parameters: given region ($REGION) and IP address of the OpenStack Networking server ($IP). You must provide admin user credentials that OpenStack Compute and some internal components of OpenStack Networking can use to access the OpenStack Networking API. The suggested approach is to create a special service tenant, create a neutron user within this tenant, and to assign this user an admin role. If you use OpenStack Networking, do not run the OpenStack Compute nova-network service (like you do in traditional OpenStack Compute deployments). Instead, OpenStack Compute delegates most network-related decisions to OpenStack Networking. OpenStack Compute proxies tenant-facing API calls to manage security groups and floating IPs to Networking APIs. However, operator-facing tools such as nova-manage, are not proxied and should not be used. When you configure networking, you must use this guide. Do not rely on OpenStack Compute networking documentation or past experience with OpenStack Compute. If a nova command or configuration option related to networking is not mentioned in this guide, the command is probably not supported for use with OpenStack Networking. In particular, you cannot use CLI tools like nova-manage and nova to manage networks or IP addressing, including both fixed and floating IPs, with OpenStack Networking. It is strongly recommended that you uninstall nova-network and reboot any physical nodes that have been running nova-network before using them to run OpenStack Networking. Inadvertently running the nova-network process while using OpenStack Networking can cause problems, as can stale iptables rules pushed down by previously running nova-network. To ensure that OpenStack Compute works properly with OpenStack Networking (rather than the legacy nova-network mechanism), you must adjust settings in the nova.conf configuration file. Each time a VM is provisioned or de-provisioned in OpenStack Compute, nova-* services communicate with OpenStack Networking using the standard API. For this to happen, you must configure the following items in the nova.conf file (used by each nova-compute and nova-api instance). Modify from the default to nova.network.neutronv2.api.API, to indicate that OpenStack Networking should be used rather than the traditional nova-network networking model. Update to the name of the service tenant created in the above section on OpenStack Identity Update to the name of the user created in the above section on OpenStack Identity configuration. Update to the password of the user created in the above section on OpenStack Identity configuration. Update to the OpenStack Identity server IP and port. This is the Identity (keystone) admin API server IP and port value, and not the Identity service API IP and port. The OpenStack Networking Service provides security group functionality using a mechanism that is more flexible and powerful than the security group capabilities built into OpenStack Compute. Therefore, if you use OpenStack Networking, you should always disable built-in security groups and proxy all security group calls to the OpenStack Networking API . If you do not, security policies will conflict by being simultaneously applied by both services. To proxy security groups to OpenStack Networking, use the following configuration values in nova.conf: Update to neutron, so that all security group requests are proxied to the OpenStack The OpenStack Compute service allows VMs to query metadata associated with a VM by making a web request to a special 169.254.169.254 address. OpenStack Networking supports proxying those requests to nova-api, even when the requests are made from isolated networks, or from multiple networks that use overlapping IP addresses. Example values for the above settings, assuming a cloud controller node running OpenStack Compute and OpenStack Networking with an IP address of 192.168.1.2.

a valueError exception will be raised because a libvirt bug of
the incorrect return value of baselineCPU() function, in function
get_host_capabilities, which introduced by commit
3b8c26321bce07b8ad588099c1fdcef858e748a8.

For libvirt interface baselineCPU() in python library, -1 will be
returned if basecpu info is None from version 1.1.2, and the return
value of this interface is corrected to None from version 1.2.0.

This patch is to fix this problem by:
 * check the return value of baselineCPU() and make sure it is not
   equal to -1
 * change the `hasattr` checking method to `has_min_version`, the
   required min libvirt version of baselineCPU flag
   VIR_CONNECT_BASELINE_CPU_EXPAND_FEATURES is 1.1.2
 * add a unit test for this bug and change the old unit test

Closes-bug: #1259796

Change-Id: I5e4cb4a8d09b660edc4f6c6a4ad4bfe58a4dd5cb

commit_message:
lxc: Fix a bug of baselineCPU parse failure

When starting nova-compute on compute node with lxc hypervisor,
a valueError exception will be raised because a libvirt bug of
the incorrect return value of baselineCPU() function, in function
get_host_capabilities, which introduced by commit
3b8c26321bce07b8ad588099c1fdcef858e748a8.

For libvirt interface baselineCPU() in python library, -1 will be
returned if basecpu info is None from version 1.1.2, and the return
value of this interface is corrected to None from version 1.2.0.

So a checking is added to make sure the return value of baselineCPU()
is not -1, and also a test case is added.

Closes-bug: #1259796

Pass extra arguments to tests.

This allows to run for example:
       tox -- --force

Also reorder elements of envlist.

commit_message:
Document lxml requirement

Document requirement on lxml installation.

Change-Id: Ifc7da810aabd54e0f6bfcd2e2053bc3d63d07ba6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/26/64726/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This package needs a few external dependencies including lxml. If you do not have lxml installed, you can either install python-lxml or have it installed automatically and build from sources. To build lxml from sources, you need a C compiler and the xml and xslt development packages installed. To install python-lxml, execute the following based on your distribution. On Ubuntu:: apt-get install python-lxml For building from source, install the dependencies of lxml. On Ubuntu:: apt-get install libxml2-dev libxslt-dev

commit_message:
Don't need session.flush in context managed by session

Within the scope of a single method, keeping all the reads and writes within
the context managed by a single session. In this way, the session's __exit__
handler will take care of calling flush() and commit() for you.
If using this approach, you should not explicitly call flush() or commit().
See http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_7/orm/session.html#committing

Closes-Bug: #1258044

Change-Id: I4f7d35e8aae67f3805a771ba8aab7c9e82511c93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/63/60163/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: session.flush() session.flush() session.flush()

commit_message:
Javascript force use of the curly braces.

    This option requires you to always put curly braces around blocks
in loops and conditionals. JavaScript allows you to omit curly braces
when the block consists of only one statement, in some circumstances,
it can lead to bugs.

Change-Id: If50546461813549b3a9cebb384eed7159c753c43
Implements: blueprint jshint-codestyle

deleted_lines: if( $(a).data("index") < $(b).data("index")) return -1; if( $(a).data("index") > $(b).data("index")) return 1;

commit_message:
GlusterFS: Use correct base argument when deleting attached snaps

When deleting the most recent snapshot, the 'file_to_merge' field
which translates into the base= field for libvirt's blockRebase
call in Nova must be set depending on whether other snapshots exist.

If there are no other snapshots, base = None, which results in
libvirt clearing the qcow2 backing file pointer for the active
disk image.

If there are other snapshots, pass the parent of the file being
deleted as the new base file.  The snapshot info pointer for the
prior base file must also be updated in this case.

Closes-Bug: #1262880
Change-Id: If7bc8259b031d0406346caafb8f688e65a38dba6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/23/63223/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Delete the newest snapshot, with only one snap present.""" vol_qemu_img_info_output = """image: %s file format: raw virtual size: 1.0G (1073741824 bytes) disk size: 173K """ % volume_file volume_img_info = imageutils.QemuImgInfo(vol_qemu_img_info_output) image_utils.qemu_img_info(volume_path).AndReturn(volume_img_info) 'file_to_merge': None, """Delete the middle of 3 snapshots.""" vol_qemu_img_info_output = """image: %s file format: raw virtual size: 1.0G (1073741824 bytes) disk size: 173K """ % volume_file volume_img_info = imageutils.QemuImgInfo(vol_qemu_img_info_output) image_utils.qemu_img_info(volume_path).AndReturn(volume_img_info)
deleted_lines: """Delete the newest snapshot.""" 'file_to_merge': volume_file, """Delete the middle snapshot."""

commit_message:
Add UUID verification and UUID test case in object fields

For UUID type, verify whether it is UUID or not, and add unit test for UUID
field.

Change-Id: I612b52f5fe97ac05e334284f0e10b84b70edfa77

deleted_lines: # FIXME(danms): We should actually verify the UUIDness here return str(value)

subject: Add test for checking models with migrations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-16 09:13:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/2e8c7cca5a5ad222dd9160a0fcc799242b556ed7', 'message': 'Add test for checking models with migrations

Each component of OpenStack uses models as base for service
and migrations as base for creation of database.
In fact there are a lot of differences in models with migrations.
And there is no test that could find them.

This patch adds opportunity to compare actual state of DB with models
in mysql and postgres dialects.

Will be checked:
- tables with shadow_tables,
- columns (name, type, lenght, default, nullable),
- constraints (indexes, unique constraints and foreign keys).

Also there is a alembic support for project which use alembic repo
as base or auxiliary.

bp: sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I415e11864a1859cf074e4e55eb610ae8ce96e8c5

'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2013-08-23 11:47:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/b069a645d00c2fa3059c160c19c61cd920493496', 'message': 'Add test for checking models with migrations

Each component of OpenStack uses models as base for service
and migrations as base for creation of database.
In fact there are a lot of differences in models with migrations.
And there is no test that could find them.

This patch adds opportunity to compare actual state of DB with models
in mysql and postgres dialects.

Will be checked:
- tables,
- columns (name, type, lenght, default, nullable),
- constraints (indexes, unique constraints and foreign keys).

Also there is a alembic support for project which use alembic repo
as base or auxiliary.

bp: sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I415e11864a1859cf074e4e55eb610ae8ce96e8c5

And there is no test that could find them.

This patch adds opportunity to compare actual state of DB with models
in mysql and postgres dialects.

Will be checked:
- tables,
- columns (name, type, lenght, default, nullable),
- constraints (indexes, unique constraints and foreign keys).

Also there is a alembic support for project which use alembic repo
as base or auxiliary.
For each test it's own database will be used.
After ending all temporary databases will be removed.

bp: sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I415e11864a1859cf074e4e55eb610ae8ce96e8c5
