a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I7e04f31e32ce882241726776c79e14a151a79325

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.

Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for

	with which permission level.

"}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2013-08-28 15:39:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/083e624205a42b60639bb2f56e1f45a1f929fe44', 'message': "Add Volume ACL Permissions: API extension

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 3. API extension
    Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'entity_id': <entity_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-15>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I7e04f31e32ce882241726776c79e14a151a79325

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: API extension

Implementation:
Part 4. API extension
    Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'project', # or 'group'
                 'entity_id': <entity_id>,
                 'access_permission': <access_permission>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I7e04f31e32ce882241726776c79e14a151a79325
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/83/39683/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_volume_permission(self, context, volume_id): return self.db.volume_permission_get_by_user(context, volume_id) def get_all_volume_permissions(self, context, volume_id): return self.db.volume_permission_get_all_by_volume(context, volume_id)

subject: Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-23 12:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/9348048417c97791ec9b9eb39f2f58833259ca6f', 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL API

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-08-23 13:14:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/25257602f7f060af170b08e626b4f647788c750a', 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects)
            checks if user is admin of any of projects in projects list;
        * get_user(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) user ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject is group ID, or fails with NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48

"}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2013-08-28 14:22:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e050859f0cdcc725c298a98f854f0e7823103cf6', 'message': "Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So it is used here by default, but you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects)
            checks if user is admin of any of projects in projects list;
        * get_user(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) user ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject is group ID, or fails with NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects)
            checks if user is admin of any of projects in projects list;
        * get_user(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) user ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or 'everyone' key word,
            where subject is group ID, or fails with NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

    Note, that in a class for work through Keystone Identity Service
    v2.0 keystone client is used as well as v3 keystone client.
    It's due to some functions are implemented in the only version of
    keystone client, e.g. users.check_in_group is implemented in v3
    version only and then we should use v3 keystone client, but
    there is no roles.roles_for_user or any analogs in v3 version,
    in v2.0 only, then we should use v2.0 version for checking
    user(other user, not user_id from context) is admin.
    This will be fixed when it's possible.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: Volume ACL Module

Implementation:

Part 2. Volume ACL Module
    Add CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
    Add an interface to work with users and user groups data.
    Not all the openstack deployments use Keystone as Identity Service.
    So you can implement your own class depending
    on another Identity Service and specify it in the config.
    Implemented class should contains the following methods:
        * check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id);
        * get_project(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) project ID or '*' key word
            for everyone,
            where subject can be user ID or name, or fails with NotFound
            exception;
        * get_group(self, subject)
            returns existing(means validated) group ID or '*' key word
            for everyone, where subject is group ID, or fails with
            NotFound exception.
    Also you can use another implemented class, but there will be
    no functionality with user groups and admins.

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I1537e1462ddb08f72b32b96a085e3ed98efaad48

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright (c) 2013 Mirantis Inc. # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Unit Tests for volume acl.""" import datetime from cinder import context from cinder import db from cinder import exception from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder import test from cinder.volume.volume_acl import api as volume_acl_api from cinder.volume.volume_acl import identity LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class VolumeACLPermissionTestCase(test.TestCase): """Test cases for volume ACL code.""" def setUp(self): super(VolumeACLPermissionTestCase, self).setUp() self.ctxt = context.RequestContext(user_id='user_id', project_id='project_id') def fake_get_subject(self, subject): return subject def fake_check_user_in_group(self, user_id, group_id): return True def fake_check_user_is_admin(self, user_id, projects): return False self.stubs.Set(identity.API, 'get_user', fake_get_subject) self.stubs.Set(identity.API, 'get_group', fake_get_subject) self.stubs.Set(identity.API, 'check_user_in_group', fake_check_user_in_group) self.stubs.Set(identity.API, 'check_user_is_admin', fake_check_user_is_admin) def _create_volume(self, volume_id, status='available', user_id=None, project_id=None, ctxt=None): if not ctxt: ctxt = self.ctxt if user_id is None: user_id = ctxt.user_id if project_id is None: project_id = ctxt.project_id vol = {'id': volume_id, 'updated_at': datetime.datetime(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1), 'user_id': user_id, 'project_id': project_id, 'display_name': 'Display Name', 'display_description': 'Display Description', 'size': 1, 'status': status} volume = db.volume_create(ctxt, vol) return volume def test_volume_permission_create_update_delete(self): acl_api = volume_acl_api.API() volume = self._create_volume('1') new_access_permission = 7 new_user = 'new_user_id' new_perm = acl_api.create(self.ctxt, volume.id, new_user, access_permission=new_access_permission) self.assertEquals(new_perm.access_permission, new_access_permission) self.assertEquals(new_perm.type, 'user') self.assertEquals(new_perm.user_or_group_id, new_user) new_owner_permission = 1 new_owner_perm = acl_api.create(self.ctxt, volume.id, self.ctxt.user_id, access_permission=new_owner_permission) self.assertEquals(new_owner_perm.user_or_group_id, self.ctxt.user_id) nctxt = context.RequestContext(user_id=new_user, project_id=self.ctxt.project_id) self.assertRaises(exception.WrongAccessPermissionLevel, acl_api.create, nctxt, volume.id, self.ctxt.user_id, access_permission=new_owner_permission) upd_access_permission = 1 new_perm = acl_api.create(nctxt, volume.id, new_user, access_permission=upd_access_permission) self.assertEquals(new_perm.access_permission, upd_access_permission) self.assertEquals(new_perm.type, 'user') self.assertEquals(new_perm.user_or_group_id, new_user) perm = acl_api.create(context.get_admin_context(), volume.id, self.ctxt.user_id, access_permission=new_owner_permission) self.assertEquals(perm.id, 2) self.assertEquals(perm.access_permission, new_owner_permission) acl_api.delete(self.ctxt, new_perm.id) acl_api.delete(self.ctxt, perm.id) def test_volume_permission_create_not_found_volume(self): acl_api = volume_acl_api.API() self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeNotFound, acl_api.create, self.ctxt, '1', 'new_user_id', access_permission='7') def test_volume_permission_get(self): acl_api = volume_acl_api.API() volume = self._create_volume('1') new_access_permission = 7 new_user = 'new_user_id' created_perm = acl_api.create(self.ctxt, volume.id, new_user, access_permission=new_access_permission) new_perm = acl_api.get(self.ctxt, created_perm.id) self.assertEquals(created_perm.id, new_perm['id']) volume2 = self._create_volume('2') acl_api.create(self.ctxt, volume2.id, new_user, access_permission=new_access_permission) volume3 = self._create_volume('3', ctxt=context.get_admin_context()) acl_api.create(context.get_admin_context(), volume3.id, new_user, access_permission=new_access_permission) self.assertEquals(volume3.id, '3') perms = acl_api.get_all(self.ctxt) self.assertEquals(len(perms), 2) perms_for_vol1 = acl_api.get_all_by_volume(self.ctxt, volume.id) self.assertEquals(len(perms_for_vol1), 1) perms_for_vol2 = acl_api.get_all_by_volume(self.ctxt, volume2.id) self.assertEquals(len(perms_for_vol2), 1) all_perms = acl_api.get_all(context.get_admin_context()) self.assertEquals(len(all_perms), 3) # volume permissions of volume3 (created by admin) is 3 self.assertRaises(exception.VolumePermissionNotFound, acl_api.get, self.ctxt, '3') perm = acl_api.get(context.get_admin_context(), 3) self.assertEquals(perm['id'], 3)

subject: Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-23 12:51:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f3fcd139719d3c305e4db33ab0081b66f6a74100', 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB-related changes

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

1. Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    user_or_group_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means user_or_group_id is user_id; "group" means
    user_or_group_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', user_or_group_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}
2. CRUD for VolumeACLPermission.
3. Add os-volume-acl API extension.
    Use cases:
    * create/update permission:
        POST /v2/<project_id>/os-volume-acl
        {'body':
            'volume_acl_permission': {
                 'volume_id': <volume_id>,
                 'type': 'user', # or 'group'
                 'user_or_group_id': <user_or_group_id>,
                 'access_permission': <1-7>,
            }
        }
    * show permission (by permission ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>
    * list all permissions(for all the volumes for which the user has
    'Permission Read' access) or for a volume (by volume ID):
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/detail?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * get access permission level for the volume ID:
        GET /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/access?volume_id=<volume_id>
    * delete permission:
        DELETE /v1/<project_id>/os-volume-acl/<permission_id>

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-08-27 19:47:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/917dcd9f4ccd893ad1baa103bfaab00269feaed8', 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full aceess(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission can be classifies as the following:

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
	Indicated as 1.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
	This permission includes Read permission.
	Indicated as 2.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
	Indicated as 3.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level. This permission includes Permission Read.
	Indicated as 4.
Read+Permission Read: Indicated as 5.
Write+Permission Read: Indicated as 6.
Full access: This permission inludes all the other permissions and
	equals to Write+Permission Write.
	Indicated as 7.
Read+Permission Write: Indicated as 8.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means entity_id is user_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (from 1 to 7 as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 2}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2013-12-06 14:28:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e5d40825652d8febb9980079d9116b699acb4c8b', 'message': 'Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authoritzations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a single user, a group of users, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st(most significant) bit -- Permission Write;
2nd -- Permission Read;
3rd -- Write;
4th -- Read.
Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates a user or group ID which the permission
    affects or 'everyone' keyword for all users;
    type - "user" means entity_id is user_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Write access to user_id2. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 1, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'user_id2', type:
        'user', access_permission: 3}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to all users(everyone). The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'everyone', type:
        'user', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028

commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authorizations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a group of users, users in a tenant, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st (less significant) bit -- Read/Only attach;
2nd -- Read/Write attach;
3rd -- View Permissions;
4th -- Edit Permissions;
etc.

Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates group or project ID which the permission
    affects or '*' keyword for everyone;
    type - "project" means entity_id is project_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to everyone. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: '*', type:
        'project', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/53/43453/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class VolumeACLPermission(BASE, CinderBase): """Represents ACL for a volume.""" __tablename__ = 'volume_acl_permissions' id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True) volume_id = Column(String(36), ForeignKey('volumes.id'), nullable=False) type = Column(String(10), nullable=False) user_or_group_id = Column(String(255), nullable=False) access_permission = Column(Integer, nullable=False, default=7) permission_list_access = Column(Integer, nullable=False, default=0) volume = relationship(Volume, backref="volume_acl_permissions", foreign_keys=volume_id, primaryjoin='and_(' 'VolumeACLPermission.volume_id == Volume.id,' 'VolumeACLPermission.deleted == False)') VolumeACLPermission,

commit_message:
Update iter_nodes to insert handoff when primay fail

WIP

When primary fails, the handoff will be shifted to fullfil the
node list. This would require lots of data moving when the
node rejoins the cluster in EC. By using 'insert' instead of
'shift' would save lots of work,

Change-Id: I16376e318abecd6bff4060fb832689259b8e4c2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/31/64031/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for h_node in handoff_nodes: for p_node in primary_nodes: if not self.error_limited(p_node): yield p_node if not self.error_limited(p_node): nodes_left -= 1 if nodes_left <= 0: return else: if not self.error_limited(h_node): handoffs += 1 if self.log_handoffs: self.logger.increment('handoff_count') self.logger.warning( 'Handoff requested (%d)' % handoffs) if handoffs == len(primary_nodes): self.logger.increment('handoff_all_count') yield h_node h_node = handoff_nodes.next() if not self.error_limited(h_node): nodes_left -= 1 if nodes_left <= 0: return if not self.error_limited(h_node): yield h_node if not self.error_limited(h_node):
deleted_lines: for node in primary_nodes: if not self.error_limited(node): yield node if not self.error_limited(node): nodes_left -= 1 if nodes_left <= 0: return for node in handoff_nodes: if not self.error_limited(node): yield node if not self.error_limited(node):

commit_message:
Fixing workbook events creation

* Workbook events creation is now called from a REST controller rather
 than from DB API. This is more proper place (level of abstraction).
* Fixed workbook definition controller and evets tests.

Change-Id: Ib17d0b0dae614c474c161cd12ecbb1b05aea74a8

commit_message:
Create-stack-user script should have execute permissions

Currently running stack.sh as root advises you about this script, which is not
executable

This is needed in stable/havana because grenade says to run this
version.

Change-Id: I674af044b8f3c31bcc86be5c6552e8086453d5cd
(cherry picked from commit 105c6e8718da2db50e48cb4a68be8522a80e101e)

commit_message:
API accepts only UUID for ports

The API currently accepts a MAC address in the URI query string for
ports, when it should only accept the port UUID. This is particular
unsuitable because the MAC address may change.

Change-Id: I78380e71ca9102206bed7f0fc6085726600293af
Closes-Bug: #1246816

subject: Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-01 23:49:29.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/units.py', 'tests/unit/test_units.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/969fcfbac4291a3246ab141586cd20e0a9187b66', 'message': 'Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py

In oslo, we are using lowercase k as variable for 1000, but using
uppercase M, G, T, P, E, Z, Y as variable for other unit variables.

It is better to update lowercase k to uppercase K as variable for
1000 to keep consistent.

Change-Id: I088fc9566f8d60b80914751bd6b13bd40a3528bd
'}]
commit_message:
Use uppercase K for 1000 in oslo-incubator/openstack/common/units.py

In oslo, we are using lowercase k as variable for 1000, but using
uppercase M, G, T, P, E, Z, Y as variable for other unit variables.

It is better to update lowercase k to uppercase K as variable for
1000 to keep consistent.

Change-Id: I088fc9566f8d60b80914751bd6b13bd40a3528bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/24/64624/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(units.k, 1000)

commit_message:
Add missing quota flags in the config file sample

l3 extensions don't set quota flags in the config sample file
etc/neutron.conf.
Quota is unlimited if its value is minus and not only if it's -1.

Closes-Bug: #1250574
Change-Id: I76c8d1e2676d4e9b0feeed6e504e759fe736a0db

commit_message:
Fix NoSuchOptError in lbaas agent test

Option 'periodic_interval' doesn't exist when using testtools
to test lbaas agent, fix this by adding a mock object.

Change-Id: I5ef02d6fa154ea7a18ca77d02a2704b7e3990c3b
Closes-Bug: #1264260

commit_message:
O'Reilly Edit: Database Cluster Clarification

Clarifies statement about db clustering recommendation.

Change-Id: I4cbbbd62dad1e4311d14b8667d47a91d6bfe1685
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/72/64472/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>OpenStack Compute uses a SQL database to store and retrieve stateful information. MySQL is the popular database choice in the OpenStack community. </para> <para>Loss of the database leads to errors. As a result, we recommend that you cluster your database to make it failure tolerant. Configuring and maintaining a database cluster is done outside of OpenStack and is determined by the database software you choose to use in your cloud environment. MySQL/Galera is a popular option for MySQL-based databases.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Most OpenStack Compute central services, and currently also the nova-compute nodes, use the database for stateful information. Loss of this ability leads to errors. As a result, we recommend that you cluster your databases in some way to make them failure tolerant.</para>

commit_message:
Add base utils for keystone benchmarks

This patch introduce keystone benchmarks with keystone base utils
+ add 2 keystone benchmark scenarios:
1) create_user - just create user one by one
2) create_delete_user - create & delete user

Add tests for utils and benchmarks

Samples included

blueprint keystone-benchmark

Change-Id: I9362135877bb1bc904fc8ed93c74eba89686e78a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/29/64329/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import random import string from rally.benchmark import base # TODO(boris-42): Bind name to the uuid of benchmark. def get_keystone_name(length=10): """Generated random name for keystone resources.""" rand_part = ''.join(random.choice(string.lowercase) for i in range(length)) return TEMPLATE + rand_part class KeystoneScenario(base.Scenario): """This class should contain base operations for benchmarking keystone, most of them are creating/deleting resources. """ @classmethod def _user_create(cls, name_length=10, password=None, email=None, **kwargs): """Creates keystone user with random name. :paramn name_length: length of generated (ranodm) part of name :param **kwargs: Other optional parameters to create users like "domain", "project", "password". """ name = get_keystone_name(length=name_length) # NOTE(boris-42): password and email parameters are required by # keystone client v2.0. This should be cleanuped # when we switch to v3. password = password or name email = email or (name + "@rally.me") return cls.admin_clients("keystone").users.create(name, password, email, **kwargs) @classmethod def _user_delete(cls, user): """"Delete keystone user.""" user.delete()
deleted_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4

commit_message:
Initial rubocop support.

Per the mailing list thread, introducing Rubocop as a replacement for Tailor.
Assuming Jenkins likes this, more pedantic patches will follow to make Rubocop
happy.

commit_message:
Import venv setup from oslo-incubator

Import usual venv tools for easier python development.
This includes setup of openstack-common.conf.

Update .gitignore for changes.

Change-Id: I9d08bbbe10f4692fbd409b26238cc033a382cc24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/01/64601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2010 United States Government as represented by the # Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. # All Rights Reserved. # # Copyright 2010 OpenStack Foundation # Copyright 2013 IBM Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import sys import install_venv_common as install_venv # noqa def print_help(venv, root): help = """ Openstack development environment setup is complete. Openstack development uses virtualenv to track and manage Python dependencies while in development and testing. To activate the Openstack virtualenv for the extent of your current shell session you can run: $ source %s/bin/activate Or, if you prefer, you can run commands in the virtualenv on a case by case basis by running: $ %s/tools/with_venv.sh <your command> Also, make test will automatically use the virtualenv. """ print(help % (venv, root)) def main(argv): root = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__))) if os.environ.get('tools_path'): root = os.environ['tools_path'] venv = os.path.join(root, '.venv') if os.environ.get('venv'): venv = os.environ['venv'] pip_requires = os.path.join(root, 'requirements.txt') test_requires = os.path.join(root, 'test-requirements.txt') py_version = "python%s.%s" % (sys.version_info[0], sys.version_info[1]) project = 'Openstack' install = install_venv.InstallVenv(root, venv, pip_requires, test_requires, py_version, project) options = install.parse_args(argv) install.check_python_version() install.check_dependencies() install.create_virtualenv(no_site_packages=options.no_site_packages) install.install_dependencies() print_help(venv, root) if __name__ == '__main__': main(sys.argv)

commit_message:
Move nova benchmark samples to nova directory

We are going to have nova/cinder/glance/keystone specific benchmarks
so it will be better to have separated directoires for samples for
each group of benchmark scnearios.

Change-Id: I3bdbcba64e87d8f86a6bb8d2f5c5698a0e343cfe
